hints_html: We can use implicit differentiation to find the slope of the tangent line (and subsequently the equation of the tangent line). Don’t forget to apply the product rule to the xy term!
hints_latex:
We can use \textbf{implicit differentiation} to find the slope of the
tangent line (and subsequently the equation of the tangent line). Don't
forget to apply the product rule to the \emph{xy} term!
hints_raw: We can use '''implicit differentiation''' to find the slope of the tangent line (and subsequently the equation of the tangent line). Don't forget to apply the product rule to the ''xy'' term!
question: 1 (f)
sols_html:
Using implicit differentiation with respect to x, we see that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac{d}{dx} (xy + x^2 + 1) \\ &= (1 \cdot y + x \cdot \frac{d}{dx} \, y) + 2x + 0 \\ &= y + x \, \frac{dy}{dx} + 2x \\ &= \frac{y + 2x}{1 - x} \end{aligned}\]

and substituting in the point \(\displaystyle (-1,1)\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx} &= \frac{y + 2x}{1 - x} \\ &= \frac{1 + 2(-1)}{1 - (-1)} = \frac{-1}{2} \end{aligned}\]

We use the slope-point formula to determine that the equation of the tangent line at \(\displaystyle (-1,1)\) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} y - 1 &= \frac{-1}{2} (x - (-1)) \\ y - 1 &= \frac{-1}{2} x - \frac{1}{2} \\ y &= {\color{blue} \frac{-1}{2} x + \frac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}\]
